I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
of up to $40,200,000 ($28,900,000 to be disbursed in Kazakhstani tenge equivalent—unless the 
cross currency swap market is unavailable, in which case ADB will disburse this amount in US 
dollar—and  $11,300,000  to  be  disbursed  in  US  dollar)  to  LLP  RG  Brands  Kazakhstan  for  the 
RG Brands Agribusiness Project in Kazakhstan. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Project Identification and Description 

1. 

Project Identification 

2. 
Kazakhstan is an upper middle-income country. From 2000 to 2008, the economy grew 
at an average annual growth rate of 9%, one of the highest rates in the world. The share of the 
population living below the subsistence line, however, is still at 5% nationwide and 9% in rural 
areas.1
 The global financial crisis of 2008–2009, which interrupted Kazakhstan’s growth, was a 
reminder  of  the  need  to  sustain  gains  of  the  past  to  improve  prospects  for  the  future. 
Kazakhstan  needs  to  diversify  its  economy  and  reduce  its  dependence  on  oil  and  other 
extractive  minerals,  which  accounted  for  22%  of  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  and  63%  of 
exports  in  2010.  To  diversify  and  transcend  its  middle-income-country  challenge,  Kazakhstan 
needs to increase its productivity and competitiveness. The private sector will ultimately lead the 
transformation  of  the  economy  by  increasing  productivity  and  diversity  via  innovation  and 
entrepreneurship.2 
 
3. 
The  government’s  industrial  development  program  for  2010–2016  lists  the  ―agro-
industrial complex‖ as a priority sector for the diversification of the economy and a sector with 
strong export potential.3 Agriculture has a huge growth potential in Kazakhstan thanks to its vast 
territory  and  its  proximity  to  large  growth  markets  (People’s  Republic  of  China,  Russia,  and 
India).  Total  agricultural  land  is  about  2.1  million  square  kilometers,  of  which  89%  is  pasture 
land  and  11%  is  arable  land.  Grains,  meat,  dairy  products,  and  processed  food  have  great 
potential  to  successfully  compete  in  the  global  market.  Although  agriculture  contributed  only 
about 5% of GDP, its employment contribution was about 25% of the total working population in 
2010.4  
 
In  December  2011,  ADB  staff  met  the  top  management  of  the  RG  Brands  group  (RG 
4. 
Brands)—one of the leading producers of milk, juice, and tea in Kazakhstan—and assessed the 
financing needs and strategic fit.  RG Brands was found suitable for ADB assistance based on 
its solid operational and financial track record. In 2007, RG Brands received a $50 million loan 
from the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) for the construction of a 
production  site  in  Aksengir,  near  Almaty.  In  February  2012,  RG  Brands  applied  for  ADB’s 
assistance to fund its capital expenditures over the 2013–2015 period (including the expansion 
of  milk  and  juice  production  facilities  and  the  purchase  of  coolers  and  delivery  trucks)  and  to 
refinance a portion of its debt maturing in the short term. 
                                                
1   Government  of  Kazakhstan.  Agency  of  Statistics  website:  www.eng.stat.kz  (accessed  on  18  March  2013). 
According  to  the  Organisation  for  Economic  Co-operation  and  Development  (OECD),  which  defines  the  poverty 
line as 60% of the national median-equalized household income, the poverty rate is 17% nationwide and exceeds 
25% in some rural areas (source: OECD. 2011. Kazakhstan Sector Competitiveness Strategy. Paris.).    

2  ADB. 2012. Country Partnership Strategy: Kazakhstan, 2012–2016. Manila. 
3   Government  of  Kazakhstan.  2010.  State  Program  of  Accelerated  Industrial  and  Innovative  Development  of  the 

Republic of Kazakhstan, 2010–2014. Astana. 

4   OECD. 2011. Kazakhstan Sector Competitiveness Strategy. Paris. 

 

 2 

 

The  project  is  central  to  RG  Brands'  strategy  of  increasing  the  local  content  of  its 
5. 
products,  improving  production  and  distribution  efficiency,  maintaining  and  expanding  direct 
access  to  customers,  and  increasing  exports  to  neighboring  countries.  The  project  is  also 
consistent  with  the  objectives  of  the  government’s  industrial  development  program  for  the 
agribusiness  industry,  which  include  securing  national  food  independence,  increasing  added 
value  by  16%,  increasing  per  capita  productivity  from  $3,000  to  $6,000,  and  increasing  the 
share of agriculture products in the country’s total exports from 3.5% in 2010 to 8.0% by 2015. 
 

2. 

Project Design 

6. 
The  project  consists  of  (i)  the  expansion  of  RG  Brands’  ultra-high  temperature  (UHT) 
milk  and  juice  production  facilities  ($14.9  million),  (ii)  investments  to  boost  efficiency  in 
production and distribution ($15.3 million), and (iii) the refinancing of debt maturing in the short 
term ($10.0 million) to compensate for the lack of long-term debt financing in the market. 
 
7. 
ADB’s  financing  will  help  improve  UHT  milk  production  in  the  Kostanay  plant  (in  the 
north of Kazakhstan). The funds will be invested in milk collection systems, particularly in trucks 
that  will  collect  raw  milk  from  dairy  farms  and  households  in  different  parts  of  the  Kostanay 
region  and  deliver  it  directly  to  the  plant.  The  investment  will  also  enhance  production  and 
storage facilities in Kostanay. Finally, RG Brands will build a similar UHT milk production unit in 
Aksengir, within the existing Aksengir production center. 
 
8. 
RG  Brands  sources  raw  milk  from  farmers  in  the  Kostanay  region.  In  2011,  the  group 
started implementing a new system of working with dairy farms by providing long-term contracts 
to  dairy  farms,  which  in  turn  can  use  these  to  obtain  financing  from  local  banks.  RG  Brands 
works with 11 dairy farms and eight villages where small household farmers supply their milk to 
the plant. As a pilot project, RG Brands invested $500,000 in the Turar Dairy Farm in Kostanay 
to help it purchase milk equipment and provide working capital. As a result, RG Brands secured 
a  reliable  supply  of  high-quality  milk.  The  farm  created  150  new  jobs  and  included  new  water 
treatment and a water supply system for the Turar village. ADB financing would help RG Brands 
further expand such initiatives. 
 
To  help  sustain  the  growth  of  the  juice  business,  RG  Brands  plans  to  invest  in  the 
9. 
improvement  of  its  juice  production  facilities  in  Aksengir  (e.g.,  pasteurization,  blending,  and 
syrup  preparation),  as  well  as  in  a  new  juice  production  line  in  Kostanay.  About  25%  of  the 
concentrates  and  purees  used  by  RG  Brands  are  sourced  from  farmers  in  Kazakhstan, 
supplying peaches, tomatoes, and apples. RG Brands works closely with two juice concentrate 
factories  from  the  Almaty  region.  Additional  investment  in  similar  facilities  will  be  required  to 
meet  RG  Brands’  increasing  demand  in the  coming  years  while  sustaining the  level  of quality. 
RG Brands’ parent, Resmi Group, is planning to launch an agribusiness private equity fund that 
would invest in juice concentrate factories and fruit farms, thus helping increase the proportion 
of locally made concentrates used in the production of RG Brands juices. 
 
10. 
Given the large territory of Kazakhstan, efficient distribution is critical. RG Brands works 
with about 40,000 small convenience stores, more than half of which are in rural areas. Usually, 
these convenience stores are owned and run by families that lack the financial resources to buy 
their  own  equipment,  such  as  coolers  and  racks  for  store  products  like  milk  and  juices.  RG 
Brands plans to maintain its annual investment in coolers for these shops. To further increase 
distribution  efficiency,  it  is  launching  a  new  pilot  project  to  finance  delivery  trucks  that  will  be 
leased to individual entrepreneurs. Finally,  RG Brands’ investment plan includes investment in 
power system modernization, required to ensure production efficiency.  
 

 3 

RG Brands has about $60 million of debt maturing in 2013 and 2014, out of its total debt 
11. 
of  about  $75  million  as  of  December  2012.  To  extend  the  maturity  profile  of  this  debt,  it  is 
seeking  long-term  funding  from  ADB  to  refinance  $10  million  of  bonds  and  loans  maturing  in 
2013 and 2014. The extension of its debt maturity profile will enable RG Brands to increase its 
annual investment levels and ensure continuous growth. 
 

3. 

The Borrower 

RG Brands, established in 1994, is one of the leading producers of milk, juice, tea, and 
12. 
other  food  and  beverage  products  in  Kazakhstan.  With  leading  brands  and  dominant  market 
shares in key market segments, a modern production base and world-class management team, 
RG Brands is focused on becoming the largest and most efficient food and beverage group in 
Central  Asia  by  2017.  In  2012,  its  total  assets  reached  $194  million;  total  revenues  were 
$245 million;  earnings  before  interest,  tax,  depreciation,  and  amortization  (EBITDA)  amounted 
to  $36 million;  and  net  profit  was  $27  million.  The  group  is  targeting  revenues  of  more  than 
$600 million and an EBITDA margin greater than 15% by 2017. 
 
13. 
RG  Brands  has  two  main  production  centers:  Kostanay  and  Aksengir.  The  Kostanay 
plant, which RG Brands acquired from Nestlé in 2004 for a total consideration of $2.3 million, is 
its  only  milk  production  facility.  The  Kostanay  region  is  known  as  an  agricultural  center  of 
Kazakhstan  thanks  to  its  favorable  climate  and  availability  of  agricultural  land.  In  2007,  RG 
Brands,  along  with  EBRD  and  Kazakhstan  Development  Bank,  invested  $75  million  in  the 
construction of a modern production facility in Aksengir to consolidate the production processes 
in the Almaty region into a single site.  
 
14. 
RG  Brands  has  its  own  extensive,  nationwide  sales  and  distribution  platform.  Its 
10 regional  sales  offices  are  located  in  the  largest  cities  of  Kazakhstan  and  account  for  about 
75%  of  total  sales.  RG  Brands  also  works  with  eight  third-party  distributors,  each  operating 
exclusively in a dedicated region, which account for 25% of total sales. RG Brands holds the top 
three  market  positions  in  all  segments  of  operations:  UHT  milk  (23.0%),  juices  (15.3%), 
packaged tea (8.2%), carbonated soft drinks (14.8%), and ice tea (14.0%). Its exports (mainly to 
the  Kyrgyz  Republic,  Tajikistan,  Turkmenistan,  and  Uzbekistan)  reached  10.5%  of  its  gross 
sales in 2012. RG Brands plans to triple its exports by 2017.  
 
15. 
RG  Brands’  founder  and  major  shareholder  is  a  well-known  businessman,  Kairat 
Mazhibayev,  who  owns  the  business  through  Resmi  Group,  an  investment  holding  company 
that  is  also  engaged  in  real  estate,  retail,  and  asset  management.  Resmi  Group  successfully 
invested in and exited several businesses. 
 
16. 
RG Brands directly employs about 1,600 staff, who each receive benefits in compliance 
with local labor law (e.g., RG Brands pays 10% of the gross monthly salary directly to a pension 
fund  of  the  employee's  choice).  In  addition,  about  1,500  households  indirectly  depend  on  the 
RG  Brands  business  for  their  livelihood  (e.g.,  milk  farmers,  juice  concentrate  factory  workers, 
and fruit farmers). 
 
B. 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Output 

17. 
The project will contribute to (i) sustained  contribution of the agriculture sector to GDP, 
(ii) increased exports of agriculture and food products, and (iii) private sector development. The 

1. 

Impacts 

 

 4 

 

agriculture  sector’s  contribution  to  GDP  is  expected  to  remain  above  5%  from  2012  to  2019.5 
The share of agriculture and food products in total exports is expected to increase from 3.5% in 
2010  to  8.0%  by  2019,  in  line  with  the  objective  of  the  government’s  industrial  development 
program.6 The project is expected to have a demonstration effect, inducing commercial banks to 
lend  more  to  private  companies  involved  in  the  sector.  Nonsovereign  loans  granted  by 
commercial banks to agribusinesses is expected to increase from T300 billion in 2012 to at least 
T800  billion  by  2020,  in  line  with  the  government’s  plan  of  a  cumulative  T2 trillion  increase  in 
nonsovereign loans to agribusinesses over the 2013–2020 period.7 
 
18. 
The project will also strengthen national food security and food safety. It is expected to 
help  increase  the  consumption  of  safe  and  nutritious  beverage. 8  Specifically,  per  capita 
consumption of UHT milk is expected to increase from 12 liters per annum in 2011 to 17 liters in 
2017 and per capita consumption of juices from 12 liters per annum in 2011 to 20 liters in 2017.  
 

2. 

Outcome 

The project’s expected outcome will be the efficient production and distribution of quality 
19. 
food  products,  with  greater  inputs  from  local  farmers.  Production  of  UHT  milk  is  expected  to 
increase from 25 million liters per annum in 2011 to at least 50 million liters in 2017. Production 
of juices is expected to increase from 60 million liters per annum in 2011 to at least 120 million 
liters in 2017. The average time to deliver products to retailers is expected to decrease from 2 to 
3 days to 1 day. Raw milk sourced locally is expected to increase from about 20 million liters per 
annum  in  2011  to  at  least  45  million  liters  in  2017.  Juice  concentrate  sourced  locally  should 
increase from 0.5 million kilograms per annum in 2011 to 2.0 million kilograms in 2017. 
 

3. 

Output 

20. 
The  output  of  the  project  is  the  successful  completion  of  the  investment  plan  by  2015. 
The investment plan compromises the expansion of the UHT milk and juice production facilities 
in Aksengir and Kostanay, investments to boost distribution efficiency (coolers and juice racks to 
be  installed  at  small  convenient  stores,  and  delivery  trucks  to  be  leased  to  individual 
entrepreneurs), and investments to boost production efficiency. 
 
C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations  

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 and Country Strategy 

21. 
The project is consistent with Strategy 2020. Supporting agriculture and rural areas is an 
―underlying  component  of  the  inclusive  growth  strategy‖  because  ―the  majority  of  the  poor  still 
live  in  rural  areas,  and  agriculture  remains  a  source  of  productivity  improvement,  seasonal 
employment,  and  income  growth—especially  when  connected  to  urban,  industrial,  and  export 
markets.‖  By  connecting  agricultural  production  to  food  processing  and  export  markets,  the 
project will contribute to economic growth and the reduction of rural poverty in Kazakhstan. The 
project  is  also  consistent  with  Strategy  2020’s  objective  of  scaling  up  private  sector 
development and private sector operations in all operational areas.9 
                                                
5   Economist Intelligence Unit. 2012. Country Forecast–Kazakhstan. London. 
6   Footnote 3. 
7   Government of Kazakhstan. 2012. Agribusiness 2020 (2013–2020). Astana. 
8   Fruit  juices are  a  good source  of  vitamin  C  and  fiber.  UHT  milk  is  safer  than  fresh milk,  as  bacterial spores  are 
killed in the heating process, but has the same nutritional value (calcium and vitamins A, B, and D). UHT milk is 
easier to transport, allowing for a wider distribution to regions with low raw milk production. It has a long shelf life of 
6–9 months, which means that it can be stored for winter, when milk production is very low.  

9  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020. Manila. 

 5 

Under  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy,  2012–2016  for  Kazakhstan,  agribusiness  is 
22. 
one of the sectors to be supported by ADB’s private sector operations. The strategy recognizes 
Kazakhstan’s  strong  prospects  in  agriculture,  stemming  from  its  vast  arable  land  area.  The 
project  is  consistent  with  two  of  the  main  drivers  of  the  strategy—private  sector  development 
and greater regional integration—since it will support exports of high-quality food products from 
Kazakhstan  to  neighboring  Central  Asian  countries.  Through  its  demonstration  effect  on  local 
banks, the project will also contribute to the strategy outcome indicator targeting an increase in 
overall bank loans as a proportion of GDP from 39% in 2011 to 50% in 2016.10 
 

2. 

Consistency with Sector Strategy and Relevant ADB Operations 

23. 
The  project  is  aligned  with  ADB’s  agriculture  sector  strategy.  In  particular,  the 
Operational Plan for Sustainable Food Security (2009) recommends an ―expanded partnership 
with the private sector‖ in order to attract ―more direct investments in productivity enhancement, 
agro-processing,  agro-retailing  and  other  nonfarm  rural  business.‖  Assistance  to  a  food 
processor  also  incorporates  the  operational  plan’s  objective  of  ―increasing  synergy  and  value 
addition  in  the  backward  and  forward  linkages  along  the  food  and  agriculture  value  chain.‖ 
Stronger links along the value chain boost productivity, jobs, exports and regional trade, as well 
as food security for the poor in both rural and urban areas.11  
 
D. 

Project Cost and Financing Plan 

24. 
The  project,  including  the  proposed  refinancing  of  existing  debt,  is  estimated  to  cost 
around T6.0 billion, or $40.2 million, over 2013–2015. Given its current asset base ($194 million 
as of December 2012) and its low leverage ratios (debt–equity of 0.8 times and debt–EBITDA of 
1.9 times as of December 2012), RG Brands intends to finance the project solely with long-term 
corporate debt from ADB.

F. 

Arrangements 
The  project  will  operate  under  the  general  regulatory  framework  applicable  to 
manufacturing  companies  in  Kazakhstan.  The  project  does  not  operate  under  a 
concession agreement and its tariffs are not regulated. 
RG  Brands  is  led  by  a  team  of  expatriates  and  locally  experienced  managers,  with 
extensive experience in leading international food and beverage companies. 
Equipment chosen for ADB financing will be purchased and installed in 2013–2015. 
The  equipment  required 
international 
manufacturers  that  will  be  selected  based  on  competitive  bidding.  For  the  milk  and 
juice  processing  lines,  RG  Brands  works  with  world-renowned  equipment  suppliers 
such as Krones, Sidel, Tetra Pak, and Van Der Molen. 
The  project  will  rely  on  RG  Brands  for  its  successful  operation.  RG  Brands  has 
relevant and extensive experience in milk and juice production. Under already existing 
supply  arrangements,  raw  milk  is  sourced  from  local  farmers  and  an  increasing 
proportion  of  juice  concentrate  is  sourced  from  local  producers.  The  project  will  also 
benefit from RG Brands’ sales and distribution platform and marketing expertise. 
RG Brands will report on key performance indicators, including output and outcome 
indicators. 

the  project  will  be  procured 

from 

for 

Projected Financial and Economic Performance 

26.   RG  Brands’  return  on  invested  capital  is  expected  to  increase  from  19.0%  in  2012  to 
above  22.5%  from  2016  onward.  The  company  is  financially  viable  because  the  return  on 
invested capital is higher than the weighted average cost of capital of 11.8%. The company is 
also economically sustainable, as the economic return on invested capital is 24.7%, higher than 
the social discount rate of 12%. 
 
G. 

Unique Features 

The project promotes inclusive agricultural value chain development in innovative ways. 
27. 
RG  Brands  will  enter  into  long-term  procurement  contracts  with  local  dairy  farmers  and  will 
provide  critical  equipment  to  small  retailers,  enabling  them  to  participate  in  the  high-quality 
beverage  value  chain.  This  project  will  be  ADB’s  first  nonsovereign  agribusiness  project  in 
Central and West Asia. This is also the first direct nonsovereign assistance in Kazakhstan (as 
opposed to assistance through a financial intermediary). 
 

6 

25. 
 

 

 7 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Assistance 

The  proposed  assistance  is  a  senior  loan  of  up  to  $40.2  million  to  LLP  RG  Brands 
28.  
Kazakhstan. The loan will comprise two tranches: (i) tranche A in the amount of $30.2 million for 
the purpose of financing the borrower’s capital expenditures, and (ii) tranche B in the amount of 
$10.0 million for the purpose of refinancing the borrower’s debt. 
  
B. 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

29.   ADB  will  support  a  ―national  champion‖  in  a  strategic  industry  for  Kazakhstan. 
Agribusiness is not only increasingly contributing to GDP and export growth, it is also a labor-
intensive  sector  that  will  continue  to  create  jobs.  The  ADB  loan  will  help  RG  Brands  finance 
long-life productive assets and reduce its exposure to debt maturing in the short term, freeing it 
to  reinvest  more  annual  earnings  in  annual  capital  expenditures  to  support  its  growth.  RG 
Brands’ suppliers will also expand their businesses in response to the company’s growth, which 
in turn will generate indirect employment. 
 
30.   ADB  will  add  value  by  providing  long-tenor  financing,  which  is  not  readily  available  for 
private sector companies in Kazakhstan. Accessing long-term debt has become a challenge for 
companies of the size of RG Brands since the 2008–2009 financial crisis. Only the government 
and large conglomerates are now able to raise bonds, as pension funds (the main bond buyers) 
are  subject  to  new  prudential  norms.  The  commercial  bank  market  has  become  almost 
exclusively  short  term,  since  the  proportion  of  short-term  funds  on  banks’  balance  sheets  has 
also increased as a reaction to the crisis, which caused several Kazakh banks to default on their 
long-term  obligations.  Nonetheless,  well-run  medium-sized  private  sector  companies  like  RG 
Brands still need long-term funding to support their growth. 
 

IV. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

A. 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

31. 
In compliance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), the project is classified as 
category  B  for  environment  and  category  C  for  both  involuntary  resettlement  and  indigenous 
peoples. A corporate and compliance audit conducted on RG Brands’ environmental and social 
management  system  (ESMS)  and  existing  facilities  showed  that  the  company’s  systems  on 
occupational  health  and safety  and food  safety  are  satisfactory.  However,  waste management 
and  pollution control  need  to  be  improved.  A  corrective  action  plan  has  been  prepared,  which 
the  company  has  committed  to  implement  and  which  will  be  incorporated  in  the  company's 
initial  environmental  examination  and  corresponding  environmental 
revised  ESMS.  An 
management  plan  have  been  prepared  for  the  proposed  investment  plan.  RG  Brands  will 
ensure that the potential environmental and social impacts of the overall project are recognized, 
and  that  effective  measures  to  avoid,  minimize,  mitigate,  and  compensate  for  the  adverse 
impacts  are  incorporated  in  the  safeguard  plans.  RG  Brands  has  committed  to  step  up  its 
institutional  capability  to  manage  the  project’s  social  and  environmental  impacts,  adopt  an 
ESMS agreed on with ADB before the first disbursement, and submit annual monitoring reports. 
Information disclosure and consultations with affected people are conducted in accordance with 
ADB requirements. 
 
32.   ADB  will  ensure  that  the  investment  documentation  includes  appropriate  provisions 
requiring RG Brands to comply with national labor laws and the internationally recognized core 

 

 8 

labor  standards  for  the  ADB-financed  portion  of  the  project,  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Social 
Protection Strategy.12  
 
B. 

Anticorruption Policy and Anti-Money Laundering Policies 

33. 
RG Brands was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption policy (1998, as amended to date), and 
policy  relating  to  the  Combating  of  Money  Laundering  and  the  Financing  of  Terrorism  (2003). 
Consistent  with its  commitment to governance, accountability  and transparency,  ADB  requires 
that  RG  Brands  institute,  maintain  and  comply  with  internal  procedures  and  controls  following 
international  best  practice  standards  for  the  purpose  of  preventing  corruption  and  money 
laundering  activities  and  the  financing  of  terrorism  and  to  covenant  with  ADB  to  refrain  from 
engaging in such activities. 
 
C. 

Investment Limitations  

The  proposed  loan  is  within  the  medium-term,  country,  industry,  group,  and  single-

34. 
project exposure limits for nonsovereign investments. 
 
D. 

Assurances 

Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  the 
35. 
Government  of  Kazakhstan’s  no  objection  to  the  proposed  assistance  to  RG  Brands  will  be 
obtained. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation, in form and substance satisfactory 
to ADB, following approval of the proposed assistance by the Board of Directors. 
 

V. 

RECOMMENDATION 

36. 
I am satisfied that the proposed loan would comply with the Articles of Agreement of the 
Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and,  acting  in  the  absence  of  the  President,  under  the 
provisions  of  Article  35.1  of  the  Articles  of  Agreement  of  ADB,  I  recommend  that  the  Board 
approve  the  loan  of  up  to  $40,200,000  ($28,900,000  to  be  disbursed  in  Kazakhstani  tenge 
equivalent—unless  the  cross  currency  swap  market  is  unavailable,  in  which  case  ADB  will 
disburse  this  amount  in US  dollar—and $11,300,000 to  be  disbursed  in US  dollar)  to  LLP  RG 
Brands Kazakhstan for the RG Brands Agribusiness Project in Kazakhstan from ADB’s ordinary 
capital resources, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance with those 
set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board. 
 
 

Bindu N. Lohani 
Ranking Vice-President 

25 March 2013
